reviewText:
Early Access Review

I applaud them for having the price cheaper while in early access than it will be once it's released out of early access.  Usually it's the other way around.

That said, the game is definitely an early access game.  Content is limited.  But what there is, is good, and in my opinion it's worth investing in this game in the hope for more content.

Graphics style is gritty cartoon and caricature.  Oversized heads, bulging muscles, punches to the face, etc.  There's a lot of humor in this game and pop culture references.

It's basically a board game with cards.  You and an opponent take turns rolling dice and moving around a board.  When you land on a space there might be a neutral enemy you can either fight to get gold or hire them so that they will fight the opponent.  The battles are just one hit and then they are done, it does not continue until someone dies.  So basically you're trying to whittle down your opponents HP to zero over time.   Each game I've played has been fairly short, so it's not like a long drawn out campaign.

You can use cards to lay down friendly minions, spells to harm enemies, movement spells to move you where you want to go, and other options.   But those cost action points to use and you only have so many action points per turn.

There are different characters you can play and they each have their own special abilites and cards.  That makes for a nice variety in playstyle.

tl;dr breakdown:


Card game on a square board. (or a board game with cards!)
Early Access
Limited content at this time with promise of more coming
Play as different characters, each with own style and cards
Short games - good for a quick gaming fix
Humor (the title scroll is hilarous)
Buy it cheap now before they increase the price!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iyyLOnpqu9s

Dicetiny is a fun little dice rolling and deck building game. In the video above we show a short preview of a game on the beginning level.

Fakedice provided a review copy of Dicetiny to The Hidden Levels and for that we thank them greatly.

My first impression was that the UI was very similar to a certain card game I play on occasion. The artwork is very similar in the deckbuilder only however, so we can move past that. The cards are interesitng and the rest of the artwork is highly stylized in a good looking package of minions, creatures, characters, and cards.

The game mechanics are also interesting albeit not groundbreaking in terms of a board game. You roll dice to move around the board, playing cards and defeating minions until one of the two players is at zero health. The unique aspect seems to be the character abilities such as giving a minion +1 damage, or giving your character +2 attack power. That's it essentially, you roll dice and play cards, attempting to defeat your opponenet or minions. You can alternatively pay to hire some minions which became fun when our hero was able to give them more attack power with his special ability.

The replay value is relatively high, you can gain more cards and heros, build decks, and play consistently without it being a repetitive experience. The game is stilll in early access so the potential for more additions is more than a certainty. There are also a substantial number of gaming related easter eggs" or small jokes relating to other games. It took me a bit to realize that "Middle Board" was a play on Lord of the rings. There is a solid mix of humor
recommended: and fun that seems to make this a solid board game experience for the PC.\n\nI'd recommend picking this one up if you have any plans to play it
hoursPlayed: especially since during Early Acess it appears to be substantially discounted. The price increase will be corrolating to the addition of more content towards release and it appears that it will leave Early Access at the $20 price point. I plan on coming back to it each time they unlock more levels and content.\n\nThanks for reading / watching. Check out www.thehiddenlevels.com for previews

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DICETINY: The Lord of the Dice is a board/card game with RPG elements. This game is in Early Access, and at the moment it does not have too much content.

When I first started playing this, first thought what come to my mind that its a bit looks like Hearthstone, but this not that.
This basically a board game with cards. In every turn you and your opponent roll a dice and move around a board, the two characters moving in different way, one start a circle from left, other from right. The game will be end when someone has no more HP. If you arrive for a land with enemy, you fight , but if that enemy is neutral you have a option to hire it.

You can use a different cards, some cards boost you, some put down friendly minions, etc. If you want play a card, this cost some points what you get in every turn. At the start you have one character to play, other you can unlock when you beat them in the story mode. All heroes have own special abilities and cards as well. Also you can create your own card decks.

The graphic style is a caricatured carton, and this looks nice. Sounds and music also good.

So my verdict

+complected with humor
+nice graphics
+steam cards
+cheaper in EA than later when got full version
+fast matches

-at the moment not too much content
-no multiplayer
-no steam achievements

If you like board games you really should try out this one. This game has a good gameplay, nice graphics and humor. However at the moment not have to much content  because game is in early access now, but to compensate this, now game costs less. I think if you are interested in this, it's good to buy it now, as later will cost more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I heard about this game through Letigress' stream. My understanding is she partnered up with the developers in order to help promote the game, which is neat. So lets get into why I DO reccomend this game...
The style is very remincent of Hearthstone. The cards look slightly similar but the style is VERY different. I mean, for starters, its a board game. Games take anywhere between 5-15 minutes for a round, which I think is perfect. There is a fair amount of strategy that goes into a match. For $5, I think it is totally worth giving this game a try and seeing where the developers take it! Now... Here is what I'd like to see from the game...
-MULTIPLAYER! This game needs to let me play against my friends. That's like 80% of the appeal. I've already beat all the bots. Give me new game modes. This should be the developers first priority.
-Card variety. Right now the starter deck gets stale after 3-5 hours. There is very little you can do with it at the moment. This game needs 100+ cards to REALLY start to be something special.
-More characters. This is a given and the developers know this. I'm excited to see what they come up with. The abilities of the NPCs you can play seem neat.
-Let the text and dialogue move at the player's pace. Create like a Next" arrow when interactions and stuff are happening. Everything moves so fast right now and I missed a lot of it when I first started.
-New boards. The board now is cool
date: but I'd like more stuff to happen on it and in the future even have different boards that aren't as simple as a single square. Maybe something that can accomodate more than two players?\n\nThat's all I have for now. I'll update as the developers do. You should get this game. It is cheap and a lot of fun! I only have 1.4 hours shows while I write this
recommended: but played offline for 5ish hours. I'll probably play 5 or so more on this patch then wait for updates. Thank you to Letigress for turning me on to this! :)\nCheers."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game hits the target demographic that Culdcept, Guild of Dungeoneering, and Card Hunter does, with sarcastic humor and good board/card game design and card play. Right now it's early access, so the game is very incomplete, but something to put on your watch list to buy for sure when its ready to go!

The game is a deck building game, but played on a board where you roll dice to move around, and deal with the challenges on each space through your characters abilities or cards you can play from your deck, all the while fighting the larger threat of the boss you must fight who is also traversing the board.  It has good strategy elements, fun graphics, and a touch of randomness that can make you cheer or cry out in agony when that one die roll does or doesn't go your way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It seems like it was trying really hard to be Culdcept, but it just didn't quite make it. The content is pretty minimal, but I expected that from an early access game. The main issue is that the core gameplay is very similar to Culdcept, but it lacks the depth that made those games fun (cards and spaces don't have suits, the decks are much smaller, a card's attack is the same as it's defence, etc.). The only area where it matches Culdcept is in quality of the writing. Which is terrible.

Overall, I'm kinda disappointed. If they add a TON of content it might have some charm, but the gaps in the core game design are almost too big to fill with fluff. I don't hate it, but it left me even more bummed out that no one has made a decent Culdcept port/copy.

Suggestions for the dev team:
-Add multiplayer support
-Add a card trading mechanic (I feel like I shouldn't have to say this)
-Get a native English speaker to do the writing for you
-Go replay Culdcept and copy it better

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dicetiny is a ton of fun, even while in early access mode. It reminds me of magic with a condensed monopoly board, in that the corner spots are special- a shop, a dungeon, and a buffer zone. I can't wait for the full release, so far there is only one area with 4 different characters to battle. Once you win against a character you can create a deck for that character and battle as them. Each character deck has its own strength and weakness. If you're looking for a single player board game (I always am) and enjoy card game elements, I strongly suggest you try this game.

EDIT: New Update has changed game so my review may be a bit inaccurate until I replay and can re-evaluate.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm a huge fan of boardgame style video games like Culdcept and Talisman, so this really caught my interest. It just released in Early Access today, and I have no regrets about buying early, especially with the super low price tag right now. I'm very pleasantly surprised by how polished the game is already. Gameplay feels like a cross between Hearthstone and Monopoly. You roll dice to move and use ability points to use spell cards, unique character abilities, or place static monsters on the board as obstacles for your opponent. It's fun, and I'm looking forward to seeing what the devs add as time goes on!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like this game, i've been looking for a single player board game type game and this is exactly that. A few problems here and there that I will talk about later, but first, the good.

Good:

- Very nice art, looks unique and fits nicely.
- The concept is very nice and fills a spot in my library that I had been wanting to fill for a while.
- The variety is nice, from what I have played so far there are a nice amount of monsters, cards, enemies, variations and so on, always could be more but it's is nice for the time being.

Critisism's:

- I find myself looking at the screen at times wondering where I have seen the same screen from. This game borrows from many other games and sometimes it works, and sometimes it doesnt. The thing I like the least is the obvious hearthstone copying of the deeck builder as well as the card backs. Sure it doesn't effect the gameplay but it still makes the game feel a bit cheap.

- I have found myself at a point in the game (the wolf enemy) where I get destroyed against him/her but easily win the prior rounds. Im talking no-hope lose from round 3 destroyed gainst the wolf. At the moment it is hard to tell if it is something I am doing wrong, or whether my class just cant beat the character. It gets very frustrating.

It is hard to say whether iI recommend this game, I have made it as far as i can (because of the wolf boss that i simply cannot beat), but I had fun coming this far. It is also very cheap at the moment.

... In conclusion I think you should wait for the game to come out completely, and then go on sale before you get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Early Access Review]

Dicetiny is a very entertaining game, and it is also pretty hilarious with low jokes and freaky references from the very first second.

Gameplay-wise it may strike as very random at first, and it is, but as soon as you get the mechanics and start building a strategy you can curve the odds in your favour. It's a game with dice, so it will always have a degree of unpredictibility on any turn.

There are some minor tweaks to polish the user interface and translation, and some mechanics like deck-building are not very interesting due to the lack of content. I presume that when it is finished it will be pretty unique.

The game doesn't take itself very seriously, and this is good. You start playing it and suddenly you have spent 3 hours on it. I did enjoy the innovative gameplay and hope to get more content soon!

voteText:
Monopoly. Primarily it's a game of chance though some strategic application will improve your odds. As such I will primiraly being making comparision contrasts to help review this concept.

One of my complaints is that in tweaking the Monopoly formula Dicetiny replaces purchasing property tiles with placing minions that can be defeated/removed/stolen and the result is a bit underwhelming. It removes the decisions between keeping resources or spending them in hopes of at least a small future or short term benefit but with the possibly of a huge payoff in the long run feel. That very decisions is what makes Monoploy somewhat interesting.  I say somewhat interseting concept because while the decisions set in front of you will change based on the dice roll/RNG/Random element of a particular game of Monopoly the overall strategy of each game is essentially the same (focusing on purchasing properties in a few key areas and not in others). I believe this is a result of having a fixed "permenant" gameboard that the elements are subject to is partially (maybe entirely?) to blame here and Dicetiny forgoes that particular dilema with the ability to randomize the board to  and the last half of each game tends to be a long jog to an inevitable conclusion.

So in short form for this Monopoly variation the non-permenancy (totally a word I'm sure) spin on purchasing obstacles (properites in Monopoly and Units or Minions in Dicetiny) seems to accomplish the task of making the game less vanilla. Unfortunately it also waters down the spend/invest decision that makes Monopoly anything more than a game of pure chance. It's an intersting problem to face and I will be intersted to see what this group comes up with.

Stay Tuned....

Good Start!.....but its basically a demo at the moment sooooooooo.....hold off on purchase until they add some of that content stuff.

At the moment you can play 4 scenarios on one difficulty setting and choose between four decks with some very light customization options to mix up the cards.

NO LONGER CRASHING ON STARTUP per update."

My verdict? Bring on updates, bring on multiplayer (Please?) and some more content will make this a well rounded game!

This is still VERY early access. I'd go so far as to call it an open alpha. The game lags consistantly and that's the best that it runs. I'm playing on a fairly new Macbook so it's not hardware and I haven't ruled out formatting issues.

As far as actual gameplay goes Dicetiny unapologetically rips from Hearthstone, even down to their card designs and abilities. Though I am looking foreward to a collectable card game that is not pay-to-win. I already play Mtg and I don't need to spend the rest of my income on virtual cards...

The other major source of insperation for gameplay is Monopoly, thats where the board game part of the formula comes in. If you've ever played monopoly just imagine Dicetiny as a hybrid of that and Hearthstone and thats all thats about all thats going on here aside from the... humor"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a fun little game!

Ok, so this game is in early access.  So because of this, as I write this review, it's very unfinished.  There's currently only one 'zone' that you can play on.  But what I see is a great start.

The basic premise is a board game mixed with a card game.  The best way I can describe it is if you took Blizzard's hearthstone card game and combined it with a board game.  You play your minions on the board and travel around the board in opposing directions from your enemy.  When you land on a square you encounter any minions or effects on that square, be they good or bad.

I look forwards to future updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fun little tcg.
Currently only single player.
Very incomplete, as of this review there are 4 missions to play (I beat them all in 15 mins) and Ive only seen 13 different cards that you can add to your deck. Your max deck size is 15 and you can have 2 of each card in your deck.
Your opponents have a wider variety of cards than you but you never get to use them.
Also you can aquire different cards from the store during the match but they cant be a part of your core deck when creating a deck.

The goal is to get your opponents health to 0.
Each player can purchase a draw on each turn provided they have the gold and use these cards to summon monsters, buff your character/monsters or cast a variety of spells using AP which rises by 1 per turn until a max of 7. AP is also used to use hero abilities, each hero has 2 unique abilities.
The way the turns are set up is alot like monopoly, you roll dice and can land on;
monsters (chose to fight or hire them to work for you),
community chest type spaces,
a dungeon (beat the monster and add it too your hand),
a store to buy a card where you can buy a card to add to your hand
and another square where you can buy upgrades for your heros stats
also after each lap you gain 100 gold and you get 50 gold for each monster you kill along the way.

So in conclusion this is a great game but considering how much content is currently available, this is little more than a demo at this point. I have heard rumors that on full release, this will be a $20 game and honestly if the rest is as good as this, its easily worth the price, assuming they fix some minor bugs

I reccomend it, even if you just let it sit in you library until more content comes out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Hearthstone and Monopoly, this game does quite well. It's currently early access, and by early access I mean it's brand freaking new. There's not much to do yet but even so, it's a lot of fun and has so much potential I'm confident it will turn into something great.

So far you've got a total of 5 playable characters, and 4 scenario battles you can play. You essentially play a hearthstone style minion game with cards and AP, while also using gold to buy resources (and sometimes use abilities) while you move around a twenty space board.

It is early access and as such has some glitches and issues, but I can definately see this becoming a great pvp game in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game seems really super duper fun. One problem. I have tried installing it on three diferent computers and it only sort of works on one of them. The top of the line gaming PC. From what I have played, the puns are good and the art style silly and engaging.  I also love the sound effects.  This has the potential to be a really nice low budget (for you) indie game. I mean, SUPER AWESOME sound effects music and little bits of voice acting.  I just wouldn't fork out the cash now.  Wait for them to get their code straight. Even on the super cool gaming PC it crashes before I can get to the second stage of story mode.

So, I will not recomend this now because of technical difficulties. BUT: if they fix them I will happily ammend my review.

Oh! And props to whoever was the art director on this project. Nice job.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Video Review & Gameplay
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Naa7ZgiJtI

DiceTiny sells itself as a dice and card based board game, augmented with abilities and gold. This sounds great and I was really excited however the game is extremely unbalanced, and almost random. My first game I tried playing minions which for the most part just got killed by my opponent with no effect to him, often 2-3 at a time. Which was followed shortly after with me pretty much 1 hitting him for a large chunk of his health. There is also a lot of small problems, for example the opponents turn moves so fast you often can’t read your opponents cards, so you have no idea what’s going on and how your opponent just killed all your stuff with 1 card. There is no description of what abilities do, I had a card with absorb, but have no clue what it does. The Game is Early access so I can excuse the extremely limited Deckbuilding and lack of other features, but just note this if you choose to buy. I have also heard of crash issues but didn’t have any myself. I could mention a lot of other small things, but ultimately the game isn’t really worth your money at this point I might keep an eye on the patch notes for improvements.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here's my video of one entire game versus the computer AI and a basic explanation of how it works and plays:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4VUJQOczfOk

Wow!  There's quite a few of these little dice and card games available, but none of them that I have played are nearly as much fun and as well designed as this game.

This game is just early in development when it launched today on October 22, 2015, but it already plays and runs like a finished game with lots of pizazz and glimmer.  This game is as cleverly designed as it's own name of the game is.. Dicetiny.. Destiny" - get it? Hehe.

Okay
date: imagine a board game where you roll dice to move in the opposite direction around the board as your AI opponent
recommended: each of you having a goal to knock or see your opponet's health drop to or below 0 health points.  So you take turns rolling the dice to move around
hoursPlayed: getting more powerful and aquiring more gold every time you pass your starting square on the board (Think Monopoly passing Go rewards).  In the special locations on the board you might land on the temple where you can spend your gold for very nice attack bonuses
voteText: health boosts
helpfulPercent: or action point increases!  Other corners you might land on with your dice roll could be a hand store to buy a very special card to hold in your hand
votesHelpful: or a dungeon where you battle an increasingly more difficult monster each time it's defeated
votesTotal: but each also rewarind the winner with more rewards.  There are also trapped locations or occupied spots where you must either fight or hire random creatures to aid you in taking out your opponent.  This game offers a great balance of strategy with all of the choices you make
commentsCount: when to spend it and what to spend it on
column16: as well as luck with dice rolls and the timing of cards drawn etc.  Think RPG
column18: and Monopoly all mixed into a perfect combination with a nice touch of humor and unique artistic style.\n\nTo be honest
column19: this is a brilliant little game that offers a HUGE bang for your dollar.  You can build your decks
column21: choose and win different cards and heroes
column22: and play a game that will vary so much that each game will ever be the same as the one before.\n\nMy score even this early in it's development is a very solid and impressive 87%.  Watch my video to get a better understanding of why and how I came up with my score... or better yet just buy this game now and thank me later!  :-)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy this today, downloaded on my home pc, go to work, downloaded on my studio (office) and... ENJOY 2 hours or so for the POLISHED EARLY ACCESS GAME EVER procrasination for my responsibility at work! MUAHAHAHAHA... Oh, I'm such a bad girl. XD

Anyway, looking forward to MOAR UPDATES! If you love digital tabletop games like this or ARMELLO, consider buy this on EARLY ACCESS! It's being polished. Can't wait for the FULL VERSION OF IT!!! Lots of PARODY as well, a fun to read here and there BUT to developer, I have some notes on artistic side:

1. The typeface, it's too fast to read when they (the heroes and villains) 'chat' before battle.
2. The character animation too fast as well... I know it's a 'static' animation for each one of them, but consider to make it more fun to be seen.

Thank you and have a nice day!

Love,

Sherly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IntroductionReady to save Middle Board from the evil sage Dead Serious? DICETINY: The Lord of the Dice is a Card-boiled Tabletop RPG Under the Influence" where Parodies and Puns are sandwiched between Fantasy and Popular Culture!

What I think about this gameDICETINY: The Lord of the Dice made me think of Hearthstone and Monopoly while playing. All the puns and refrences packed into this game is nothing to laugh at.
You are set with the task of controlling a character around a game board by rolling dice and using cards with the goal of knocking out your opponent. A game worth your time if you enjoy humor and unique gameplay.

ConclusionFilled with puns and multiple movie and culture refrences
date: DICETINY: The Lord of the Dice is a comedic
voteText:
role-playing board game.
8.5/10
